sen.j: 家宅六神（かたくろくしん）は、神道における家宅を表す（または守る）六柱の神 (神道)の総称である。
sen.e: "Kataku Rokushin" is a generic name for the six gods (Shinto) representing (or protecting) a house in Shinto.
"Kataku Rokushin" is a generic name for the six gods (Shinto) representing (or protecting) a house in Shinto.
Kataku Rokushin is a generic name for the six gods (Shinto) representing (or protecting) a house in Shinto.

sen.j: 家宅六神は、建物の材料や構造を示したものである。
sen.e: Kataku Rokushin indicates the materials and structure of buildings.
Kataku Rokushin indicates the materials and structure of buildings.
Kataku Rokushin indicates the materials and structure of buildings.

sen.j: 六柱とも、古事記において国産みを終えた後、神産みの最初に大事忍男神が産まれた後にイザナギとイザナミの子として産まれている。
sen.e: All of the six gods were born as children of Izanagi and Izanami after Ogotooshio-no-kami was born first during kamiumi (birth of the gods), after kuni-umi (the birth of (the land) of Japan) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters).

All six gods were born as children of Izanagi and Izanami after Ogotooshio-no-kami was born first during kamiumi (birth of the gods), after kuni-umi (the birth of (the land) of Japan) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters).

All six gods were born as children of Izanagi and Izanami after Ogotooshio-no-kami was born first during kamiumi (birth of the gods), after kuni-umi (the birth of (the land) of Japan) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: 石土毘古神
sen.e: Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami
Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami
Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami

sen.j: 最初に産まれたのは石土毘古神（いわつちびこのかみ）である。
sen.e: The first to be born was Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami.
The first to be born was Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami.
The first to be born was Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami.

sen.j: 家の材料である石と土（壁土）を表している。
sen.e: It represents the materials for a house, stones and soil (plaster).
It represents the materials for a house, stones and soil (plaster).
It represents the materials for a house, stones and soil (plaster).

sen.j: 石巣比売神
sen.e: Iwasuhime-no-kami
Iwasuhime-no-kami
Iwasuhime-no-kami

sen.j: 2番目が石巣比売神（いわすひめのかみ）である。
sen.e: The second was Iwasuhime-no-kami.
The second was Iwasuhime-no-kami.
The second was Iwasuhime-no-kami.

sen.j: 石巣は石砂のことであり、その前が「毘古」のつく男神であるため、対の神として女神とされたものと考えられる。
sen.e: Iwasu means stones and sand, and since the former was a male god with 'biko,' it is believed that this was a goddess to make these gods a pair.
Iwasu means sand and stone, and since the former was a male god with 'biko,' it is believed that this was the goddess that made these gods a pair.
Iwasu means sand and stone, and since the former was a male god with 'biko,' it is believed that this was the goddess that made these gods a pair.

sen.j: 『古史伝』では、この二神は上筒男神の別名であるとしている。
sen.e: "Koshi-den" describes that these two gods are the other name for Uwatsutsunoo-no-kami.
"Koshi-den" describes that these two gods are the other name for Uwatsutsunoo-no-kami.
"Koshi-den" describes that these two gods are the other name for Uwatsutsunoo-no-kami.

sen.j: 『神名考』では、石土毘古神は土を、石巣比売神は砂を司る神であるとしている。
sen.e: "Shinmeiko" (神名考) describes that Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami is the god of stones and Iwasuhime-no-kami is the god of sand.
sen.cmt: 神名考→Shinmeiko［正しい読み方が不明です］
sen.e: "Shinmeiko" (神名考) describes that Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami is the god of stones and Iwasuhime-no-kami is the god of sand.
"Shinmeiko" describes that Iwatsuchibiko-no-kami is the god of stones and Iwasuhime-no-kami is the god of sand.
sen.cmt: (神名考) 削除→読み方不明

sen.e: Otohiwake-no-kami
Otohiwake-no-kami
Otohiwake-no-kami

sen.j: 3番目は大戸日別神（おおとひわけのかみ）である。
sen.e: The third was Otohiwake-no-kami.
The third was Otohiwake-no-kami.
The third was Otohiwake-no-kami.

sen.j: 「大戸」は家の出入口のことである。
sen.e: Oto' is the entrance/exit of a house.
Oto' is the entrance/exit of a house.
Oto' is the entrance/exit of a house.

sen.j: 性別は不明である。
sen.e: The gender is unknown.
The gender is unknown.
The gender is unknown.

sen.j: 『古事記伝』では直毘神と混同された神であるとしている。
sen.e: In "Kojikiden" (Commentaries on the Kojiki), it is described as a god confused with Naobi no kami.
In "Kojikiden" (Commentaries on the Kojiki), it is described as a god confused with Naobi no kami.

sen.j: 『神名考』では、門の神の一つであるとしている。
sen.e: "Shinmeiko" describes that it is one of the gods of gates.
"Shinmeiko" describes that it is one of the gods of gates.

sen.j: 天之吹男神
sen.e: Amenofukio-no-kami
Amenofukio-no-kami
Amenofukio-no-kami

sen.j: 4番目は天之吹男神（あめのふきおのかみ）である。
sen.e: The fourth is Amenofukio-no-kami.
The fourth is Amenofukio-no-kami.
The fourth is Amenofukio-no-kami.

sen.j: 「吹」は屋根を葺く動作を表す。
sen.e: Fuki' describes the movement of thatching the roof.
Fuki' describes the movement of thatching the roof.
Fuki' describes the movement of thatching the roof.

sen.j: 『古事記伝』では、その名前から大祓詞に登場する気吹戸主（いぶきどぬし）と同神と解釈している。
sen.e: In "Kojikiden," it is interpreted as the same god as Ibukidonushi appearing in Oharae no kotoba, due to its name.
In "Kojikiden," it is interpreted as the same god as Ibukidonushi appearing in Oharae no kotoba, due to its name.

sen.j: 『神名考』では屋上の神としている。
sen.e: In "Shinmeiko," it is the god of rooftop.
In "Shinmeiko," it is the god of rooftops.

sen.j: 大屋毘古神
sen.e: Oyabiko no kami
Oyabiko no kami
Oyabiko no kami

sen.j: 5番目に産まれた大屋毘古神（おおやびこのかみ）は、葺き終わった屋根を表す。
sen.e: Oyabiko no kami, who was the fifth to be born, represents the roof that has been thatched.
Oyabiko no kami, who was the fifth to be born, represents the roof that has been thatched.
Oyabiko no kami, who was the fifth to be born, represents the roof that has been thatched.

sen.j: この神名は、「大禍」の意味の「大綾」から「あ」が取れたもので、災厄を司る禍津日神と同神である。
sen.e: The shinmei (name of god) comes from 'oaya,' which means 'major disaster,' with the 'a' removed, and it is the same god as Magatsuhi no kami (evil gods), the god of disaster.
The shinmei (name of god) comes from 'oaya,' which means 'major disaster,' with the 'a' removed, and it is the same god as Magatsuhi no kami (evil gods), the god of disaster.
The shinmei (name of god) comes from 'oaya,' which means 'major disaster,' with the 'a' removed, and it is the same god as Magatsuhi no kami (evil gods), the god of disaster.

sen.j: 大国主の神話に登場し、五十猛神の別名ともされる「大屋毘古神」とは別神とされる。
sen.e: It appears in the mythology of Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region), and is considered a different god from 'Oyabiko no kami,' which is another name for Isotakerunokami.

It appears in the mythology of Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region), and is considered a different god from 'Oyabiko no kami,' which is another name for Isotakerunokami.

sen.j: 風木津別之忍男神
sen.e: Kazamotsuwakenooshio-no-kami
Kazamotsuwakenooshio-no-kami
Kazamotsuwakenooshio-no-kami

sen.j: 最後に産まれたのが風木津別之忍男神（かざもつわけのおしおのかみ）である。
sen.e: The last to be born was Kazamotsuwakenooshio-no-kami.
The last to be born was Kazamotsuwakenooshio-no-kami.
The last to be born was Kazamotsuwakenooshio-no-kami.

sen.j: この神は、神名からすれば風に関する神、暴風から家を守る神として、家宅六神の最後に入れられたものと考えられる。
sen.e: According to its shinmei, this god is believed to have been placed at the end of Kataku Rokushin as a god related to wind, or god protecting the house from storm wind.
According to its shinmei, this god is believed to have been placed at the end of Kataku Rokushin as a god related to wind, or god protecting the house from storm wind.
According to its shinmei, this god is believed to have been placed at the end of Kataku Rokushin as a god related to wind, or god protecting the house from storm wind.

sen.j: しかし、風の神はその後シナツヒコ（しなつひこ）が産まれており、風木津別之忍男神の「風」は単なる宛字で風の神ではないとする説もある。
sen.e: However, with regards to god of wind, there is Shinatsuhiko born later, so some say 'kaza' of Kazamotsuwakenooshio-no-kami is simply a substitute character, and it is not a god of wind.
However, with regards to god of wind, there is Shinatsuhiko born later, so some say 'kaza' of Kazamotsuwakenooshio-no-kami is simply a substitute character, and it is not a god of wind.

sen.j: 読みについても、原文の註記に「木は音を用いる」とあるので「も」と読むことになるが、神名に字音を用いるのは異例である。
sen.e: Regarding its reading, it is written 'use on (Chinese reading) for 木' in the original note, so it is read 'mo,' but it is rare to use Japanese pronunciation of a kanji (based on adopted Chinese pronunciations) in shinmei.

sen.j: 『古事記伝』では、この註は後で誤って挿入されたものであるとして「かざけつわけおしを」と読むとしている。
sen.e: In "Kojikiden," it is described that this note was mistakenly inserted later, and that it is read 'Kazaketsuwakeoshiwo.'
In "Kojikiden," it is described that this note was mistakenly inserted later, and that it is read 'Kazaketsuwakeoshiwo.'
In "Kojikiden," it is described that this note was mistakenly inserted later, and that it is read 'Kazaketsuwakeoshiwo.'

sen.j: また、『古事記伝』では、底筒男神、または大祓詞の速佐須良比売と同神としている。
sen.e: Additionally, in "Kojikiden," it is considered the same god as Sokotsutsuo-no-kami, or Hayasasura-hime from Oharae no kotoba.
